block.p: The Economy
The unemployment rate is actually higher than now reported and thousands of full-time workers hold only part-time jobs, according to new data-collection methods. [ Page D1. ]
The New York Stock Exchange will cut some customer fees 15 percent to combat shrinking market share. [ D1. ]
The Economy
The unemployment rate is actually higher than now reported and thousands of full-time workers hold only part-time jobs, according to new data-collection methods. [ Page D1. ]
The New York Stock Exchange will cut some customer fees 15 percent to combat shrinking market share. [ D1. ]
Oil demand rose significantly in 1992 because of the recovering economy. It was the first rise since 1988. [ D2. ]
Treasury Secretary Brady said the economy was strengthening and warned against a short-term stimulus program. [ D2. ]
The Treasury Department issued a broad revision of tax regulations for foreign companies. [ D8. ]
California gave a group of oil companies approval to ship crude in tankers along the environmentally sensitive coastline. [ A22. ] Companies
Wall Street was expecting good earnings news from Intel, but nothing like the profits and sales figures it reported. [ D1. ]
Pier 1 Imports became a success as an importer during the last 30 years. Now it plans to go into the export business. [ D1. ]
The Air Force expects McDonnell Douglas to file a huge claim for cost overruns in developing the C-17 transport. [ D5. ]
Eight aluminum companies will cut production because of an electricity shortage in the Pacific Northwest. [ D5. ]
Northwest Airlines scaled back its fare discounts after Delta undercut new Northwest prices announced Monday. [ D5. ]
Sears sold its Sears Business Centers, a mostly corporate business, in a continued refocusing on consumer retailing. [ D5. ]
Procter & Gamble's recycled plastic bottle for Ultra Downy fabric softener has some environmental disadvantages. [ D5. ]
Sales of domestic vehicles fell 3.1 percent in early January. But the results are considered an unreliable indicator. [ D6. ]
Volkswagen confirmed it would cut about 30,000 jobs worldwide and set up a new five-year investment plan. [ D6. ]
NBC has failed to keep David Letterman, and he is virtually certain to accept CBS's offer, network officials said. [ A1. ] International
Western Germany's economy posted its worst annual growth rate in a decade, hurt by high domestic interest rates, the recession and disruptions in world currency markets. [ D1. ] Markets
Broad stock market averages posted impressive gains but the narrower Dow fared less well, falling by 1.08 points. [ D10. ]
Treasury bonds rose but the credit market was mostly unchanged, with Iraqi hostilities having little impact. [ D18. ]
The dollar was mostly mixed and gold lost ground after rising in Asia. [ D19. ] Oil prices ended only modestly higher. [ D19. ] Today's Columns
Ignoring the Federal deficit forwards the bill for today's spending to future generations. Economic Scene. [ D2. ]
Boeing shares are losing altitude as its backlog shrinks because sickly airlines are deferring orders. Market Place. [ D10. ]
Levi Strauss wants its Dockers line to compete with the likes of Lauren and Klein. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ D21. ] The New Stock Tables

The Times has introduced new stock market tables to improve legibility and provide additional information about trading volume and price changes. The new tables use some abbreviations that differ from those formerly used.
Readers who need assistance in finding stocks, or in understanding the new tables, may call (212) 556-5899, which will be answered from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. through Friday.
